awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Biosynthesis of polyunsaturated fatty acids in marine bacteria
awd_abstract_narration:
This research award in the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program supports work by Professor Abel Baerga-Ortiz at the University of Puerto Rico to lead an investigation into how omega-3 fatty acids are made by marine micro-organisms using a polyketide synthase enzyme complex. The structure and mechanism of the different enzyme components will be studied separately using enzyme kinetics, site-directed mutagenesis and x-ray crystallography. The goal of the research is to delineate exactly (i) how these enzymes work and (ii) whether they can be altered to produce new compounds which resemble the parent fatty acid molecule in structure and physical properties. In addition, the PI will supervise a course aimed at Puerto Rican science undergraduates, graduates and faculty members, but open to science journalists and communicators, to raise awareness about the history and current status of natural products chemistry in Puerto Rico and the Caribbean, with an emphasis on its potential to develop new technologies and new enterprise. This initiative will link well with on-going outreach efforts by the PI with the Puerto Rico Medicinal Plants Garden and with workforce re-training efforts with the Puerto Rico Chemists Association.

Omega-3 fatty acids have tremendous potential as therapeutics, food additives, lubricants or biofuel components. Detailed knowledge about how omega-3 fatty acids are made in nature could be used to expand the chemical diversity of this class of useful compounds.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-CAREER project titled "Biosynthesis of polyunsaturated fatty acids in marine bacteria" consisted of three (3) major scientific aims, plus one aim to enhance the public understanding of the proposed science. 

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs), also known as omega-3 fatty acids, are extremely important compounds in human nutrition, agriculture and biotechnology. PUFAs are efficiently made by several species of deep-sea bacteria using a previously undescribed enzyme chemistry that is fundamentally different from the one observed in land-based bacteria. Our laboratory sought to study mechanistic and structural aspects that were unique to the enzymes from the deep-sea systems and never seen in land-based enzymes.

The scientific aims of our work centered on the biochemical mechanism by which PUFAs are made in these deep-sea bacteria.  We aimed to answer the following questions: 1) How are PUFAs made in deep-sea bacteria? 2) How do deep-sea enzymes differ structurally and functionally from land-based enzymes? and more importantly 3) Can we use the knowledge obtained from the deep-sea enzymes to increase the production of fatty acids in bacterial fermentations for applications which range from pharmaceuticals to biofuels?

With the support of the NSF, we were able to answer many of these questions while also driving the project in the direction of its practical applications. We first solved and reported the crystal structure for a thioesterase that is presumed to catalyze the release of PUFAs and enhance PUFA production. We also used surrogate substrates to show that this thioesterase has a preference for long-chain PUFAs, as would be expected from its putative activity. We also determined the structure for the multi-acyl carrier protein (ACP) portion that is so well conserved in these PUFA synthase enzymes. By using small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) technique we were able to show that the tandem ACP domains are arranged like beads on a string and connected through unstructured linkers. Finally, we explored the applications of a tandem dehydratase domain that is conserved in the PUFA synthases. By expressing this tandem DH construct we were able to enhance production of fatty acids in Escherichia coli grown in the laboratory, providing a possible tool in the renewable production of fatty acids. 

Altogether, our results shed light on how the deep-sea bacteria make PUFAs with high yield and efficiency. Additionally, we have been able to identify features of the deep-sea bacterial enzymes that could be incorporated into terrestrial ones in efforts to enhance industrial production.

Efforts are underway to make artificially linked versions of the ACP from E. coli expecting that the multimerization of the ACP will cause an increase in fatty acid yield, as has been observed in the deep-sea enzymes. Additionally, E. coli dehydratases, FabA and FabZ, are being forced into artificially linked constructs that more closely resemble the deep-sea enzymes. Preliminary results show that linking together FabZ results in a higher stability and a higher enzymatic activity.

Our pusuit of these research goals has led us to two international collaborations: with Dr. Hidetoshi Okuyama in the University of Hokkaido in Japan and with Dr. Gabriel Moncalián in the University of Cantabria in Santander, Spain. With Okuyama we have been able to refine our fatty acid extraction technique and to open new lines of inquiry in PUFA production. With Moncalián we have been able to align our interests in function with his expertise in X-ray crystallography for the determination of high-resolution crystal structures.

The educational aim of our proposal consisted in a series of activities aimed at educating the public about the importance of chemical diversity and natural product chemistry for technological and economic development in our region. Many of these activities were organized in collaboration with the local ACS chapters and the Caribbean Division of the AAAS, of which the PI was president from 2013-2015. Additionally, during the last 7 months the PI was named director of a local initiative for biological conservation, the Center for Tropical Biodiversity and Bioprospecting, a new platform for the public communication of these scientific initiatives.
